content.description:
Relentlessly steep for 100 meters.  First pitch might sport chandelier ice and some bulges. Second pitch is pure power ice climbing.  Belay half way up on a shelf, on either the right or left depending on which side the first pitch is climbed.



Park 2.8 km west of the Wapta road gate at a drainage crossing under the highway.  Crane your neck up to catch a glimpse of the route 650 meters above you.  Takes an hour+ for the approach.  Be mindful of the avy conditions.

Screws

climbs.name: Jacob's Ladder
climbs.fa: Kefira Allen and Dave Thomson, March 1998

content.description:
A long, committing, and wild mixed route that has plenty of ice on either end with cruxy and steep drytooling in the middle. P1 (WI5, 20m) - Climb a steep pillar for 20m with a thin exit to a two bolt anchor on the left. Walk up about 100 meters of snow slope up to a wide and large shield of WI3 ice. P2 (WI3, 60m) - Climb lower angle ice up to mushrooms which end on an ice ledge below the hanging daggers and a two bolt belay. P3 (M7+, 25m) - Move right and up from the belay following 12 bolts through pumpy and steep drytooling, surmounting an overhang for the final 3 bolts to a two bolt anchor on a tiny ledge. P4 (M7-, WI5, 45m) - Move right and up into a steep corner system with insecure placements for 6 bolts, there are an additional couple bolts above that can be used depending on how the ice forms. Move left to transition onto the hanging ice and figure out how to get to the front side of the ice. Climb dead vertical ice (you're on a hanging dagger after all) for about 20 meters and then trend right where the angle eases off to an ice belay. P5 (WI4, 50m) - Climb 3 steps of steep ice with rests in between to a two bolt anchor on the left which may be hard to find. Alternatively build a belay behind the final 5 meters of ice in a sheltered cave. Descent - One double rope rappel gets you from the top to the P4 anchor. One double 60m rope rappel should get you to the P2 anchor, however be absolutely certain your ropes are touching down and tie your knots. If you built your P4 anchor too high up you will be left hanging on your ropes a few meters above the ledge with no other option but to prussik your way back up while under some massive daggers. Another 60m rappel gets you down P2 to a walk down the snow slope and a final single rope rappel will get you to the base. Heading West on Highway 1 there is a small pullout exactly 1.3km West of Wapta Rd. This pullout features a cattle gate followed by 10 meters of road that terminates into nothing. There is enough room to park one vehicle off to the side before the cattle gate.

Walk 750 meters West along the highway until you come up to a wildlife overpass going over the highway. Before the overpass on your right you should see a gate in the fence, go through the gate, trend left up a hill to gain a ridge. From the ridge drop down left into the drainage and follow the drainage all the way to the climb. Allow for 2 hours if there is snow, and bring snowshoes.

Coordinates for the drainage are 51.252977° N, -116.683422°W, coordinates for the base of the climb are  51.263866° N, -116.677036° W. Standard ice rack, 12 quickdraws at least

Mt. Hunter is about 30km East of the town of Golden and sports a significant number of pure ice and mixed routes, all of which generally have significant approaches and are on the more difficult side of the spectrum. For those up for the challenge however, you will likely find some world class climbing all to yourself.
